questions.text: Match the following pairs between column 1 and column 2 correctly. (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c

 

This question tests knowledge of specific diagnostic tests used for bacterial identification:

 

1- b. Elek's gel precipitation test is used for Corynebacterium diphtheriae to detect toxin production through immunodiffusion in agar gel, helping determine toxigenicity of isolated strains.

 

2-a. Quelling reaction (capsular swelling) is used for Streptococcus pneumoniae to detect the polysaccharide capsule when the organism is mixed with specific antisera and methylene blue.

 

3-d. String test is used for Vibrio cholerae where a positive result shows formation of a mucoid string when a loopful of bacterial colony is lifted from an alkaline medium.

 

4-c. Coagulase test is used for Staphylococcus aureus to differentiate it from coagulase-negative staphylococci by testing the ability to convert fibrinogen to fibrin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Specific diagnostic tests are used for bacterial identification: Elek's test for C. diphtheriae, Quelling for S. pneumoniae, String test for V. cholerae, and Coagulase test for Staphylococcus aureus.

questions.text: A farmer presents with history of blunt trauma to the chest. There is formation of pus from the wound. Microscopy showed mildly acid fast bacteria with branching. What is the most likely organism? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nocardia species

 

The diagnosis of Nocardia is suggested by:

 

  1. Clinical presentation - History of trauma in a farmer (occupational exposure)
  2. Microscopic features: 
    • Mildly acid-fast (1% acid-fast positive)
    • Branching filamentous bacteria
    • Gram-positive staining pattern
  3. Formation of pus indicating suppurative infection

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium tuberculosis:

 

  • While acid-fast positive, does not show branching morphology
  • Primarily causes pulmonary TB through inhalation, not through trauma
  • Strongly acid-fast, not mildly acid-fast

 

Option C. Listeria:

 

  • Not acid-fast
  • Appears as small gram-positive rods
  • Does not show branching morphology

 

Option D. Anthrax:

 

  • Not acid-fast
  • Appears as gram-positive rods with square ends
  • Does not show branching pattern
  • Though associated with occupational exposure, presents differently

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Nocardia is characterized by being:

 

  1. Mildly acid-fast (1% acid-fast positive)
  2. Shows branching filamentous morphology
  3. Common in traumatic injuries with soil contamination
  4. Important occupational pathogen

questions.text: Which of the following does not have polysaccharide vaccine?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hepatitis B

 

Polysaccharide vaccines are typically made from the polysaccharide capsule that surrounds certain bacteria. These vaccines are designed to protect against bacterial infections by inducing immunity against the polysaccharide antigens present in the capsule.

 

Hepatitis B vaccine is not a polysaccharide vaccine. It is a recombinant vaccine that uses a portion of the hepatitis B virus (HBsAg - hepatitis B surface antigen) produced in yeast cells. This vaccine does not involve a polysaccharide component as the hepatitis B virus does not have a polysaccharide capsule.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumococcal: The pneumococcal vaccine is available in both polysaccharide (PPSV23) and conjugate forms (PCV13), targeting the polysaccharide capsule of Streptococcus pneumoniae.

 

Option B. Meningococcal: Meningococcal vaccines also include polysaccharide (MPSV4) and conjugate forms (MCV4), aimed at the polysaccharide capsule of Neisseria meningitidis.

 

Option C. H. influenzae: The Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) vaccine is a conjugate vaccine that includes the polysaccharide antigen from the bacterial capsule conjugated to a protein carrier.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine, not a polysaccharide vaccine, as it targets a virus that does not have a polysaccharide capsule.

questions.text: A patient recovered from Covid-19, treated with steroids, now presents with nasal discharge for 3 weeks. What does the histopathological image indicate? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mucor

 

Explanation:

 

The histopathological image shows broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching, typical of Mucor species, suggesting a diagnosis of mucormycosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aspergillus: Typically shows septate hyphae with acute angle branching.

 

Option C. Candida: Forms yeast cells and pseudohyphae, not hyphae.

 

Option D. Trichosporon: Forms hyaline hyphae and arthroconidia, different from what is seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucor is the cause of fungal infections characterized by broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching, particularly in immunocompromised patients such as those recently treated with steroids post-Covid-19 infection.

choices.text: Information is not enough for the diagnosis

questions.text: An elderly male patient who received a kidney transplant a decade ago is presently under immunosuppressive treatment. He reports experiencing a persistent cough and shortness of breath over the past week. Microscopic examination of his sputum reveals the presence of gram-positive budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae. What is the probable diagnosis in this case? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Invasive candidiasis

 

  • The presented clinical scenario, coupled with the microscopy revealing gram-positive budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae, strongly indicates the presence of invasive candidiasis.
  • Candida albicans has a unique ability to transform frequently between three phenotypic forms in the tissue: yeast, pseudohyphae, true hyphae. This property helps it to evade host defense system.
  • Invasive candidiasis results from hematogenous or local spread of the fungi.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucor shows, broad aseptate hyaline hyphae with wide angle branching.

 

Option B. Aspergillus shows septate narrow hyphae with acute angle branching.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Invasive candidiasis is characterized by the presence of gram-positive budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae in tissue or clinical specimens, especially in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: Choose the egg belonging to the following parasite from the column B? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3

 

The above worm is Enterobius vermicularis

 

Adults are short, white, fusiform worms with pointed ends, looking like bits of white thread. The mouth is surrounded by three wing-like curricular expansions (cervical alae), which are transversely striated. as seen in the image provided in the question. The esophagus has a double bulb structure, a feature unique to this worm.

 

 

The egg is colorless and not bile-stained. It floats in saturated salt solution. It has a characteristic shape, being elongated ovoid, flattened on one side and convex on the other (planoconvex), measuring 50-60 μm by 20-30 μm. The eggshell is double-layered and relatively thick, though transparent. The outer albuminous layer makes the eggs stick to each other and to clothing and other objects. The egg contains a tadpole-shaped coiled embryo, which is fully formed, but becomes infectious only 6 hours after being deposited on the skin. Under cool moist conditions, the egg remains viable for about 2 weeks.

 

 

The correctly matched egg for the given parasite - Enterobius vermicularis is 3

 

Other choices:
 

Option A: Egg of Hymenolepsis nana
 

Option B: Egg of Tenia species 
 

Option D: Fertilized egg of ascaris
 

Educational Objective:

 

Enterobius vermicularis eggs are elongated ovoid, flattened on one side and convex on the other, with a double-layered, thick, transparent shell and contain a tadpole-shaped coiled embryo.

questions.text: The cell wall depicted below is most likely to belong to which of the following organisms?  (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aspergillus fumigatus

 

The above picture is showing the structure of fungal cell wall most likely of Aspergillus fumigatus.

 

Fungal cell wall components - The fungal cell wall contains a cell membrane with various membrane proteins, a protective layer of chitin (yellow) as well as glucans (mostly beta) and mannoproteins on its surface. Different fungal cell walls contain different glucans. For example, the cell wall of A. fumigatus contains β-1,3- and β-1,4-glucan, and α-1,3-glucan, while C. albicans contains β-1,3- and β-1,6-glucan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mycobacterium tuberculosis cell wall structure has three major cell wall features, including peptidoglycan, arabinogalactan and mycolic acid.

 

 

Option C. Mycoplasma pneumonia is bound by a trilaminar membrane that contains sterols. Cell wall is absent.

 

 

Option D. Recently, Rhinosporidium seeberi has been considered a fungus, but it was originally thought to be a protozoan parasite. Its morphologic characteristics resemble those of Coccidioides immitis: both organisms have mature stages that consist of large, thick-walled spherical structures containing smaller daughter cells (endospores). In addition, R. seeberi is visualized with fungal stains such as methenamine silver and periodic acid-Schiff, as well as mucicarmine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fungal cell wall of Aspergillus fumigatus contains β-glucans, chitin, and mannoproteins.

questions.text: Which of the following is a dematiaceous fungus? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cladosporium

 

  • The dematiaceous (brown-pigment) fungi are a large and heterogenous group of molds that cause a wide range of diseases including phaeohyphomycosis, chromoblastomycosis, and eumycotic mycetoma.
  • Among the more important human pathogens are Alternaria species, Bipolaris species, Cladophialophora (Cladosporium) bantiana, Curvularia species, Exophiala species, Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Madurella species, Phialophora species, Scedosporium prolificans, Scytalidium dimidiatum, and Wangiella dermatitidis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucor species: Incorrect Mucor species are not dematiaceous fungi. They are non-pigmented (hyaline) fungi that cause mucormycosis, especially in immunocompromised individuals.
 

Option B. Aspergillus niger: Incorrect Aspergillus niger is not a dematiaceous fungus. It is a black mold, but it does not belong to the group of dematiaceous fungi. It is a common cause of aspergillosis.
 

Option D. Blastomyces dermatitidis: Incorrect Blastomyces dermatitidis is not a dematiaceous fungus. It is a dimorphic fungus that causes blastomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cladosporium is a dematiaceous fungus, characterized by its dark pigmentation due to melanin in its cell walls, and it is associated with various diseases including phaeohyphomycosis, chromoblastomycosis, and eumycotic mycetoma.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient had a tooth extraction three days back. He now presents with a mass in the submandibular region which is otherwise asymptomatic. There is no ulcer on the oral mucosa. On drainage of the discharge, it was foul-smelling with a lot of yellow granules. They showed gram-positive filamentous rods on grams staining. What is the most likely implicated pathogen? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Actinomycetes israelli

 

This clinical history is suggestive of cervicofacial actinomycosis which is caused by Actinomyces israeli.

 

Actinomyces are non-sporeforming, filamentous, and facultative anaerobes. They are normal constituents of the oral flora within gingival crevices and tonsillar crypts and are particularly prevalent in periodontal pockets, dental plaques, and on carious teeth.

 

Actinomyces bacteria cannot penetrate healthy tissue, and mucosal breakdown is a prerequisite for infection. Poor dental hygiene, caries, oral trauma, dental extraction, and an immunocompromised status are considered to be important antecedents.

 

Cervicofacial actinomycosis or lumpy jaw is the most frequent clinical form of actinomycosis, and “lumpy jaw syndrome”, which is associated with odontogenic infection, is the most common clinical manifestation.

 

It presents as a painless or occasionally painful soft-tissue swelling involving the submandibular or perimandibular region; over time, multiple sinuses drain pus containing sulfur granules; tendency to remit and recur. There is reddish or bluish discoloration of the skin overlying the lesion, chewing difficulties (i.e., with involvement of mastication muscles) are also seen.

 

Other types -

 

  • Thoracic actinomycosis- 
    • History of aspiration (Risk factors include seizure disorder, alcoholism, and poor dental hygiene.)
    • Dry or productive cough, occasionally blood-streaked sputum, shortness of breath, chest pain pulmonary infection with fever, cough, and purulent sputum.
  • Abdominal actinomycosis- 
    • History of abdominal surgery, perforated viscus, mesenteric vascular insufficiency, or ingestion of foreign bodies (e.g., fish or chicken bones)
  • Pelvic actinomycosis- 
    • History of IUCD
    • Lower abdominal discomfort, abnormal vaginal bleeding or discharge

 

A Gram-stained smear of the specimen may demonstrate the presence of beaded, branched, gram-positive filamentous rods, with a sun ray appearance suggesting the diagnosis of actinomycosis.

 

 

Culture - Grows slowly under anaerobic conditions, on blood or serum glucose agar at 37°C. After about a week, it appears as small, creamy-white, adherent colonies on blood agar. The colonies resemble breadcrumbs or the surface of ‘molar’ teeth. On solid media, A. israeli produces spidery colonies.

 

Treatment - Sensitive to penicillin, but prolonged courses up to 6 weeks are necessary for chronic infections. Oral penicillin’s such as amoxicillin are now popular. Recalcitrant lesions respond well to tetracycline because of its good bone penetration. Surgical intervention may be necessary in chronic jaw lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chromoblastomycosis: This is a chronic fungal infection characterized by verrucous skin lesions, typically affecting the lower extremities. It does not present with the described symptoms and findings.

 

Option B. Mucormycosis: This is a severe fungal infection caused by fungi in the order Mucorales. It usually affects immunocompromised individuals and presents with rhino-orbital-cerebral or pulmonary infections, not typically associated with submandibular masses and sulfur granules.

 

Option D. Histoplasmosis: This is a fungal infection caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, primarily affecting the lungs and sometimes disseminating in immunocompromised individuals. It does not typically present with the described symptoms and findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cervicofacial actinomycosis, commonly caused by Actinomyces israelii, presents with submandibular masses, often after dental procedures, with foul-smelling discharge containing yellow sulfur granules. Gram staining reveals gram-positive filamentous rods, confirming the diagnosis.

questions.text: Affinity maturation is due to: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Somatic hypermutation

 

Affinity maturation is a process that occurs in B cells during an immune response, leading to the production of antibodies with increased affinity for their antigen. This process is primarily driven by somatic hypermutation (SHM).

 

Mechanism:

 

  • Somatic Hypermutation (SHM): This involves the introduction of point mutations at a high rate in the variable regions of the immunoglobulin (Ig) genes in activated B cells. These mutations occur in the DNA encoding the variable regions of both heavy and light chains of the antibody molecule.
  • Selection for High Affinity: B cells that produce antibodies with higher affinity for the antigen are selectively expanded. Those with mutations that increase the affinity of the antibody for its antigen are positively selected and proliferate, whereas B cells with lower affinity or non-functional antibodies are eliminated.
  • Result: This process leads to the production of high-affinity antibodies over time, enhancing the effectiveness of the immune response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isotype Switching: Also known as class switch recombination, this process changes the antibody isotype (e.g., from IgM to IgG) but does not directly affect the antigen-binding affinity.

 

Option C. mRNA Splicing: This process involves the removal of introns from pre-mRNA to produce mature mRNA, but it is not involved in affinity maturation.

 

Option D. VDJ Rearrangement: This process generates the initial diversity of the antigen receptor repertoire by recombining variable (V), diversity (D), and joining (J) gene segments. It occurs before exposure to antigen and does not contribute to the increased affinity seen in affinity maturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Affinity maturation, which results in the production of high-affinity antibodies, is primarily due to somatic hypermutation (SHM) of immunoglobulin genes in B cells, coupled with selective survival and proliferation of B cells producing high-affinity antibodies.

choices.text: Enteroaggregative E. coli produces Heat stable Enterotoxin EAST-1.
Enterohemorrhagic E. coli can cause haemolytic uremic syndrome.
Enteropathogenic E. coli acts by invading enterocytes.
Enterotoxigenic E. coli is a frequent cause of travelers’ diarrhea.

questions.text: Which of the following statements concerning infections with Escherichia coli is false? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Enteropathogenic E. coli acts by invading enterocytes.

 

Explanation:

 

Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) does not act by invading enterocytes. EPEC causes disease through a characteristic "attaching and effacing" mechanism where it adheres closely to intestinal epithelial cells and causes destruction of microvilli, but does not actually invade the cells. Instead, it remains extracellular, forming distinctive pedestals on the surface of enterocytes. This non-invasive pathogenesis is fundamentally different from truly invasive pathogens like Shigella or Enteroinvasive E. coli that penetrate and multiply within host cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enteroaggregative E. coli produces Heat stable Enterotoxin EAST-1 - This statement is true. EAEC does produce EAST-1 (enteroaggregative heat stable enterotoxin-1), which contributes to its pathogenesis. EAEC is characterized by its distinctive "stacked-brick" pattern of adherence to epithelial cells and can cause persistent diarrhea.

 

Option B. Enterohemorrhagic E. coli can cause haemolytic uremic syndrome - This statement is true. EHEC (which includes serotype O157) produces Shiga toxin that damages vascular endothelial cells, particularly in the kidneys. This can lead to hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), characterized by microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute renal failure.

Option D. Enterotoxigenic E. coli is a frequent cause of travelers' diarrhea - This statement is true. ETEC is indeed the most common cause of traveler's diarrhea. It produces heat-labile toxin (LT) and/or heat-stable toxin (ST) that stimulate excessive fluid secretion in the small intestine, resulting in watery diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The pathogenic mechanisms of E. coli vary significantly among different pathotypes: EPEC attaches without invasion, EHEC produces Shiga toxin causing vascular damage, ETEC produces enterotoxins leading to secretory diarrhea, and only Enteroinvasive E. coli (EIEC) truly invades and multiplies within enterocytes.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic infection associated with Nocardia Asteroides? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Brain abscess

 

Explanation:

 

Brain abscess is a characteristic infection associated with Nocardia asteroides. In cases of disseminated nocardiosis, the brain is the most common site of extrapulmonary infection. Nocardia species, including N. asteroides, initially cause pulmonary infection in most cases, but then can spread hematogenously to distant sites. When this dissemination occurs, brain abscess formation is the most frequently observed extrapulmonary manifestation. These brain abscesses are often multiple, have a high mortality rate, and are particularly common in immunocompromised patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diarrhea - This is incorrect because Nocardia species typically cause respiratory tract infections, subcutaneous infections, or disseminated disease, but are not characteristically associated with gastrointestinal manifestations like diarrhea. Nocardia primarily affects the lungs, brain, and skin rather than the digestive tract.

 

Option B. Secondary dissemination to the liver - While Nocardia can disseminate to various organs from primary pulmonary infection, liver involvement is not specifically identified as a characteristic or common site of Nocardia infection. The brain, skin, kidneys, bone, and muscle are more typical sites of dissemination.

 

Option D. Colonic diverticulosis - This is incorrect because colonic diverticulosis is not an infectious condition caused by Nocardia or any other microorganism. Diverticulosis refers to the presence of diverticula (small pouches) in the colon wall, which is typically related to age, diet, and genetic factors rather than infection.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Nocardia asteroides characteristically causes pulmonary infections that can disseminate hematogenously, with brain abscess being the most common manifestation of extrapulmonary nocardiosis, especially in immunocompromised hosts.

questions.text: EBV is associated with all of the following, except: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. MALT lymphoma

 

Explanation:

 

Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is not associated with MALT (Mucosa-Associated Lymphoid Tissue) lymphoma. EBV has well-established links to several specific malignancies, but MALT lymphoma is not among them. MALT lymphoma is primarily associated with chronic antigenic stimulation, particularly Helicobacter pylori infection in gastric MALT lymphomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma - This statement is correct. EBV has a strong and well-documented association with nasopharyngeal carcinoma, particularly in persons of Chinese origin. This relationship is one of the classic examples of viral oncogenesis.

 

Option B. Hodgkin's lymphoma - This statement is correct. EBV is implicated in the pathogenesis of Hodgkin's lymphoma, especially the mixed-cellularity type. The virus can be detected in Reed-Sternberg cells, which are the hallmark cells of Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Option C. Infectious mononucleosis - This statement is correct. Infectious mononucleosis, also known as the "kissing disease," is the classic clinical manifestation of primary EBV infection. It presents with fever, exudative pharyngitis, cervical lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and atypical lymphocytosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

EBV plays a significant role in various lymphoproliferative disorders and epithelial cancers including Burkitt's lymphoma, Hodgkin's lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, and infectious mononucleosis, but has no established role in the pathogenesis of MALT lymphoma.

choices.text: Uptake of genetic material by other bacteria

questions.text: Bacterial transduction occurs by? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bacteriophage

 

Transduction is a mechanism of genetic exchange in bacteria where DNA is transferred from one bacterium to another via a bacteriophage, a type of virus that infects bacteria. This process involves a phage accidentally incorporating bacterial DNA during the assembly phase within a previously infected host cell. When this phage infects another bacterium, it can introduce the previously acquired bacterial DNA into the new host's genome, facilitating genetic exchange.

 

Other methods of exchange of genetic material are:

 

  • Transformation involves the uptake of genetic material from the environment, which is released by other bacteria.
  • Conjugation is the direct transfer of DNA from one bacterial cell to another bacterial cell through a sex pilus or bridge. The transferred DNA is a plasmid, a circle of DNA that is distinct from the main bacterial chromosome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plasmids: Incorrect, as plasmids are involved in conjugation, not transduction. They are small, circular DNA molecules within bacteria that can replicate independently of chromosomal DNA.

 

Option B. Sex pili: Incorrect, sex pili are involved in conjugation, where they facilitate the direct transfer of DNA between bacterial cells.

 

Option D. Uptake of genetic material by other bacteria: Incorrect, this describes transformation, where bacteria take up DNA from their environment, not through a virus-mediated process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transduction facilitated by bacteriophages represents a crucial mechanism of horizontal gene transfer in bacteria, contributing to genetic diversity and the spread of traits such as antibiotic resistance among bacterial populations.

choices.text: MHC class II presents peptide antigen to CD4 T cells
The action of MHC II occurs via endocytic pathway
MHC Class II presents endogenous antigens
MHC II is present on antigen presenting cells

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding MHC molecules? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MHC Class II presents endogenous antigens

 

MHC Class II molecules are specifically involved in presenting exogenous antigens, ( antigens foreign to the body eg antigens of bacteria, viruses etc)  not endogenous ( self-antigens). These exogenous antigens are typically derived from organisms outside the cell, such as bacteria or viruses that have been ingested by the cell via phagocytosis or endocytosis. MHC Class II then presents peptides from these processed antigens to CD4+ T cells, triggering an immune response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MHC class II presents peptide antigen to CD4 T cells: True, which is a key component of the immune response modulation.

 

Option B. The action of MHC II occurs via the endocytic pathway: True, this pathway involves the processing of phagocytosed material.

 

Option D. MHC II is present on antigen-presenting cells: True, which is essential for initiating the immune response by interacting with CD4+ T cells.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The test kit shown in the image below works on the principle of: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immunochromatography

 

The above image shows a HbsAg card test kit which works on the principle of immunochromatography.

 

The immunochromatographic membrane is used for antigen detection, while a nitrocellulose membrane is used to absorb the antigen from a specimen. A coloured reaction appears directly on the membrane with the sequential addition of conjugate followed by the substrate. In some cases, the antigen is captured by a bound antibody directed against the antigen. These assays have the advantage of being rapid and also frequently include a built-in internal control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ELISA (Enzyme-linked Immunosorbent Assay): Uses enzyme-labeled antibodies and an enzymatic reaction to produce a detectable signal, usually a color change, and typically requires more time and equipment to perform.

 

Option C. Immunofluorescence: Involves the use of fluorescent-labeled antibodies to detect specific antigens or antibodies in a sample, requiring specialized equipment to visualize fluorescence.

 

Option D. Chemiluminescence: Relies on a chemical reaction that produces light to detect antigens or antibodies, also requiring specialized equipment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immunochromatographic tests, such as the HbsAg card test, provide a rapid, user-friendly, and effective means of testing for certain antigens or antibodies directly at the point of care. Their simplicity and speed make them invaluable tools in clinical settings, especially where quick decision-making is crucial.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with fever, loose stools, and blood in the stool. What is the enrichment medium used to isolate the organism from the stool sample? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Selenite F broth

 

The given clinical vignette of dysentery (bloody stools) and abdominal pain in a child is suggestive of bacillary dysentery most likely caused due to Shigella. Selenite F broth is used as an enrichment media for dysentery-causing bacteria like Shigella/ Salmonella.

 

Enrichment media:

 

It is used to suppress commensal bacteria while allowing the pathogen to remain viable and grow. Common examples include:

 

  • Tetrathionate broth - It inhibits coliforms and allows typhoid and paratyphoid bacilli to grow.
  • Selenite F broth - used for dysentery causing bacteria.
  • Alkaline peptone water (Option-B) - used for vibrio cholera causing watery diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Robertson cooked meat broth: This medium is primarily used for the cultivation of anaerobic bacteria, not typically involved in cases of dysentery.

 

Option B. Alkaline peptone water: This is used for the enrichment of Vibrio species, particularly in cases suspected of cholera, which typically presents with watery diarrhea rather than bloody stools.

 

Option D. Brain heart infusion broth: It is an enriched media. It is used for the cultivation of fastidious organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selenite F broth is specifically used as an enrichment medium for isolating Shigella from stool samples in cases presenting with symptoms of dysentery, characterized by blood in the stools. This selective medium helps in the effective recovery of pathogens responsible for dysentery, aiding in accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

 

Dysentery/Shigellosis is a type of food poisoning caused by infection with the Shigella species. It is spread through faeco-oral transmission. They are catalase-negative, non-lactose-fermenting, gram-negative rods, and are non-motile. It acts by inactivating the 60s ribosomal subunit thereby inhibiting protein synthesis. It causes acute onset of symptoms (fever, abdominal cramps) with dysentery and tenesmus. It also gives a positive Sereny test.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with right upper quadrant pain, calf pain, conjunctival suffusion, icterus, and fever. Examination shows tender hepatomegaly. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospirosis

 

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette is leptospirosis.

 

Leptospirosis is a zoonosis caused by spirochetes of the genus Leptospira. Patients with mild disease may present with flu-like symptoms of sudden onset, fever with chills, headache, abdominal pain, conjunctival suffusion, and myalgia. The muscle pain usually affects the calves, abdomen, and back. Mild cases can be treated with oral doxycycline, ampicillin, or amoxicillin.

 

Severe leptospirosis is rapidly progressive and is associated with high fatality. The classic presentation of the severe disease called Wei's syndrome includes the triad of hemorrhage, jaundice, and acute kidney injury. Jaundice when present can be profound and physical examination may reveal an enlarged, tender liver.

 

Temperature-pulse dissociation /relative bradycardia ( aka Fagets sign) can be seen. Moderate to severe cases are treated with intravenous penicillin, ampicillin, or ceftriaxone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chikungunya: Typically presents with fever, severe joint pain, and rash, not prominently featuring jaundice or hepatic involvement.

 

Option C. Dengue hemorrhagic fever: While this can present with fever and potential liver involvement, the hallmark is severe bleeding and plasma leakage.

 

Option D. Encephalopathy caused by hepatitis A: Generally presents with jaundice and neurological symptoms due to liver dysfunction but does not typically include calf pain or conjunctival suffusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leptospirosis should be considered in patients presenting with a combination of fever, jaundice, muscle pain, and conjunctival suffusion, especially if there is a history of exposure to potentially contaminated water. Recognizing these signs is crucial for the timely initiation of appropriate antibiotic therapy to prevent severe complications.

questions.text: A sewage worker presented with abdominal pain, jaundice, conjunctival suffusion, and blood in the urine for the past 5 days. Which of the following is the investigation of choice? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microscopic agglutination test

 

A microscopic agglutination test is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of leptospirosis.

 

Leptospira interrogans is a spirochete with hook-shaped ends found in water contaminated with animal urine, causes Leptospirosis.

 

Leptospirosis - Flulike symptoms, myalgias (classically of calves), jaundice, photophobia with conjunctival suffusion (erythema without exudate)

 

 

Weil disease (icterohemorrhagic leptospirosis) - severe form with jaundice and azotemia from liver and kidney dysfunction, fever, hemorrhage, and anemia.

 

Laboratory tests - Leptospirae can be demonstrated under the dark field microscope or by immunofluorescence.

 

Serotype-specific tests - Microscopic agglutination test (more specific)

 

  • Rapid diagnostic test to detect leptospirae - specific IgM antibodies in human sera.

 

Treatment - Penicillin or IV ceftriaxone

 

  • Doxycycline 200 mg orally given once a week is effective in prophylaxis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Widal test is used to diagnose typhoid fever caused by Salmonella Typhi and Paratyphi. Presents as stepwise increase in fever, abdominal pain, and constipation.

 

Option C. Weil-Felix reaction is a serological test used to diagnose rickettsial infections. Presents as fever, rash, and headache.

 

Option D. Paul-Bunnell test, aka the Monospot test, used to detect heterophile antibodies in case of infectious mononucleosis, caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).Presents as fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The microscopic agglutination test is crucial for diagnosing leptospirosis in symptomatic individuals, especially those exposed to potentially contaminated water environments. Early diagnosis and treatment are key to preventing severe complications like Weil's disease.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes with complaints of fever and increasing fatigue for the past week. On examination, he is febrile, hypotensive and tachycardic. The findings of microscopic examination of his peripheral blood smear are given below. What is the causative agent? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Plasmodium falciparum

 

The given clinical history and the blood smear shows multiple ring forms in RBCs are suggestive of Plasmodium falciparum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plasmodium vivax: This species typically causes less severe malaria and is characterized by enlarged, amoeboid trophozoites within the RBCs, often with Schüffner's dots. The infected RBCs may appear enlarged.

 

Option C. Plasmodium ovale: This species is similar to P. vivax and can cause relapsing malaria. It also shows Schüffner's dots and tends to infect enlarged RBCs.

 

Option D. Plasmodium malariae: This species causes a quartan fever pattern (72-hour cycle) and shows band form trophozoites within the RBCs. The infected RBCs are usually of normal size.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple ring forms in red blood cells on a peripheral blood smear are characteristic of Plasmodium falciparum infection, which causes the most severe form of malaria. It is crucial to identify and treat P. falciparum promptly due to its potential for causing severe and life-threatening complications.

questions.text: Tumbling motility is seen in: (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Listeria

 

Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive facultative anaerobic bacterium known for its distinctive tumbling motility. This motility is due to its peritrichous flagella, which allows it to move in a characteristic tumbling motion when viewed under a microscope.

 

Tumbling motility [Peritrichous Flagella]

 

Cultured on selective media like Palcam agar or Oxford agar.

 

Differential stains like crystal violet or modified acid-fast stains can be used to highlight Listeria.

 

Enrichment broths like Fraser broth or Half Fraser broth are employed to enhance Listeria recovery from samples.

 

Cold enrichment at 4°C can promote Listeria growth

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vibrio: Vibrio species, such as Vibrio cholerae, are motile due to a single polar flagellum and exhibit a rapid, darting movement rather than tumbling motility.

 

Option C. Proteus: Proteus species are known for their swarming motility, which involves rapid and coordinated movement across solid surfaces, not tumbling motility.

 

Option D. Treponema pallidum: Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis, is a spirochete with corkscrew motility. It moves in a spiral motion rather than a tumbling motion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumbling motility is a characteristic feature of Listeria monocytogenes, a gram-positive facultative anaerobic bacterium with peritrichous flagella. This distinctive movement can help in the identification of this pathogen.

questions.text: A Cattle farmer with a scab lesion in the arm. Microscopic examination shows brick/box shaped gram-positive organism with squared ends and spores in the centre. Most likely organism which is responsible for his condition is? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bacillus anthracis

 

Given clinical scenario is suggestive of cutaneous anthrax caused by Bacillus anthracis. Bacillus anthracis is a brick/box car shaped gram-positive organism with squared ends and spores in the centre. It causes zoonotic infections in humans. It is non-motile and capsulated with a characteristic polypeptide capsule.

 

It can cause -

 

  • Cutaneous anthrax
  • Pulmonary anthrax
  • Intestinal anthrax

 

 

Box car appearance/bamboo stick appearance of bacillus anthracis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Listeria monocytogens: Incorrect. Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive rod that can cause listeriosis, but it does not have the brick/boxcar shape and is not typically associated with cutaneous lesions.

 

Option C. Bacillus cereus: Incorrect. Bacillus cereus can cause food poisoning and is a gram-positive rod, but it does not typically present with the brick/boxcar shape or cutaneous lesions.

 

Option D. Streptococcus: Incorrect. Streptococcus species are gram-positive cocci and do not exhibit the described morphology or cause anthrax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bacillus anthracis, with its brick/boxcar shape and central spores, is the causative agent of cutaneous anthrax, a zoonotic infection often seen in individuals handling livestock or animal products.

questions.text: Diarrhea, falling leaf motility, 4 pairs of flagella, tennis racket shape are seen in? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Giardia lamblia

 

Explanation:

 

Giardia lamblia is a protozoan parasite that causes gastrointestinal illness, typically presenting with diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and malabsorption. The characteristic "falling leaf" motility and the presence of four pairs of flagella (eight flagella in total) are key diagnostic features.

 

Giardia lamblia exists in two forms:

 

  1. Trophozoite: The active, motile form. It has a distinctive shape often described as a tennis racket, teardrop, or monkey face. The trophozoite has two nuclei, four pairs of flagella, and two parabasal bodies.
  2. Cyst: The infective form. It is oval-shaped with a thick wall, containing four nuclei when mature. The cyst form is responsible for transmission through contaminated water or food.

 

The images provided show the trophozoite of Giardia lamblia with its characteristic features, including the flagella and the distinctive shape.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Listeria: Listeria is a bacterium, not a protozoan. It does not exhibit the described features of falling leaf motility or multiple flagella.

 

Option C. Trichomonas: Trichomonas is a flagellated protozoan but does not have the same morphological characteristics as Giardia lamblia. It typically affects the urogenital tract rather than causing diarrhea.

 

Option D. Balantidium coli: This is a ciliated protozoan that causes dysentery, not typically associated with the described motility or flagella characteristics of Giardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Giardia lamblia is identified by its unique "falling leaf" motility, presence of four pairs of flagella, and its characteristic tennis racket or teardrop shape in its trophozoite form. It is a common cause of diarrhea and gastrointestinal discomfort.

 

Additional Information:

 

Classification:

 

 

Life cycle

 

 

Malabsorption  syndrome

 

  1. Abdominal pain , Nausea and vomiting
  2. Malabsorption of fat (steatorrhea)  → leads to foul smelling profuse frothy diarrhea
  3. Malabsorption of Disaccharidase (lactose, xylose) → leading to lactose intolerance
  4. Malabsorption of vitamin A, B12 and iron
  5. Protein loosing enteropathy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive patient presents with persistent headaches, confusion, and a gradual onset of fever. A lumbar puncture is performed, revealing an elevated opening pressure and a cerebrospinal fluid analysis, showing a positive India Ink stain. What is the most likely diagnosis?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cryptococcus neoformans

 

Explanation:

 

The key points that support the diagnosis of Cryptococcus neoformans meningitis are:

The patient is HIV-positive, indicating an immunocompromised state.

The presentation of persistent headache, confusion, and gradual onset of fever is consistent with meningitis.

 

The lumbar puncture reveals an elevated opening pressure, which is seen in meningitis.

The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis shows a positive India Ink stain, which is a negative stain used to detect capsulated organisms like Cryptococcus neoformans.


Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that commonly causes chronic meningitis in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV.

 

 

Indian Ink Preparation showing Cryptococcus

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial meningitis: While the symptoms and elevated CSF pressure are consistent with bacterial meningitis, the positive India Ink stain indicates the presence of a fungal organism rather than bacteria.

 

Option B. Viral encephalitis: The symptoms and elevated CSF pressure are not typically seen in viral encephalitis, which primarily affects the brain parenchyma rather than the meninges. Additionally, the positive India Ink stain is not consistent with a viral etiology.

 

Option D. Tuberculous meningitis: Although tuberculous meningitis is a chronic form of meningitis, it is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, a bacterium, and would not result in a positive India Ink stain, which is specific for detecting Cryptococcus neoformans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that can cause meningitis in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV.

 

A positive India Ink stain on CSF analysis, along with elevated opening pressure and compatible clinical symptoms, strongly suggests Cryptococcus neoformans meningitis.

questions.text: Safety pin appearance is seen in: (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Burkholderia pseudomallei

 

Safety pin appearance is seen in Burkholderia pseudomallei.

 

  • It is a Gram-negative bacterium that causes melioidosis.
  • Culture-based methods, including selective agar media, are used to grow and identify Burkholderia pseudomallei.
  • Molecular techniques, such as polymerase chain reaction (PCR), can be used for more rapid and specific detection.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemophilus influenza: This is a Gram-negative coccobacillus that does not exhibit a safety pin appearance. It causes respiratory infections and invasive diseases such as meningitis and epiglottitis.

 

Option C. Pseudomonas aeruginosa: This is a Gram-negative rod that does not show a safety pin appearance. It is known for its blue-green pigment and fruity odor, and it causes infections in immunocompromised patients and those with cystic fibrosis.

 

Option D. Burkholderia cepacia: This is a Gram-negative bacillus related to Burkholderia pseudomallei but does not typically show a safety pin appearance. It causes respiratory infections, particularly in individuals with cystic fibrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The safety pin appearance on Gram stain is a distinctive feature of Burkholderia pseudomallei, the causative agent of melioidosis. Recognizing this staining pattern can aid in the rapid identification and diagnosis of this potentially serious infection.

questions.text: A 30-year-old worker named John presents with swollen lymph nodes in his left armpit. He recently got bitten by fleas while working in a wheat godown. The affected area is red and tender. To investigate the cause, a smear from his axillary lymph node is examined. Which is the most suitable stain for this examination? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Giemsa

 

Solution

 

﻿﻿Diagnosis: Plague

 

﻿Done by: Yersinia pestis

 

﻿﻿Lab diagnosis

 

﻿﻿Tissue Biopsy + Giemsa stain/Wayson stain shows Bipolar stained appearance (safety pin appearance)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gram stain: While Gram stain can be used to identify gram-negative bacteria like Yersinia pestis, it is not as specific as Giemsa stain for showing the characteristic bipolar staining.

 

Option C. Acid fast: Acid-fast stains are used primarily for mycobacteria, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, and are not suitable for Yersinia pestis, which is not acid-fast.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For suspected cases of plague caused by Yersinia pestis, the Giemsa stain is the most suitable stain for identifying the characteristic bipolar staining of the organism in clinical specimens.

questions.text: A diabetic patient is presenting with a mucous discharge involving his orbital cavity was found to be spreading from nasal cavity with. Blackish discoloration what is the organism responsible? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mucormycosis

 

The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of mucormycosis. Mucormycosis is an opportunistic invasive fungal infection caused by fungi in the order Mucorales, including species of Rhizopus, Mucor, and Lichtheimia. This infection is particularly dangerous for immunocompromised individuals, such as those with diabetes, especially if it is poorly controlled.

 

Key characteristics of Mucormycosis:

 

  • Blackish discoloration of affected tissues
  • Involvement of the nasal cavity and orbital region
  • Rapid progression
  • High mortality rate if not treated promptly

 

Risk factors:

 

  • Diabetes (especially diabetic ketoacidosis)
  • Immunocompromised states (e.g., neutropenia, organ transplantation, hematologic malignancies)
  • Prolonged corticosteroid use

 

Treatment:

 

  • The drug of choice (DOC) for mucormycosis is Amphotericin B.
  • Surgical debridement of necrotic tissue is often necessary.
  • Control of underlying conditions (e.g., diabetes) is critical to improving outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Histoplasmosis: Incorrect. Histoplasmosis is typically caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, a fungus that primarily affects the lungs. It does not usually present with blackish discoloration or involve the orbital cavity.

 

Option C. Aspergillosis: Incorrect. Aspergillosis, caused by Aspergillus species, can affect the sinuses and lungs but is less likely to cause the extensive blackish necrosis seen in mucormycosis.

 

Option D. Streptococcus: Incorrect. Streptococcus species are bacteria that can cause various infections but do not present with the black necrotic tissue characteristic of mucormycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucormycosis, especially in diabetic patients, can lead to black necrotic lesions and rapid spread from the nasal cavity to the orbital region. Prompt diagnosis and treatment with Amphotericin B and surgical debridement are essential.

questions.text: Neonatal meningitis is caused by? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Streptococcus agalactiae

 

Explanation:

 

Neonatal meningitis, which occurs in newborns up to 28 days old, can be caused by various pathogens. The most common cause of neonatal meningitis is Streptococcus agalactiae, also known as Group B Streptococcus (GBS). This bacterium is a leading cause of both neonatal sepsis and meningitis.

 

Streptococcus agalactiae is a Group B beta-hemolytic streptococcus and is known for its positive CAMP test and Hippurate hydrolysis test. These tests help in the identification and confirmation of the bacteria.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Group A streptococci: Although Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) can cause various infections, it is not the primary cause of neonatal meningitis.

 

Option C. Neisseria meningitidis: This bacterium is a common cause of meningitis in older children and young adults but is not the primary pathogen in neonatal meningitis.

 

Option D. H. influenzae: Haemophilus influenzae can cause meningitis in children, particularly those aged 2 months to 3 years, but it is not the most common cause in neonates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of neonatal meningitis is Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B Streptococcus).

 

MC Causes of Acute Pyogenic (bacterial) Meningitis

 

  • Neonates: Group B streptococcus (Str. agalactiae)
  • 2 months to 3 years: Pneumococci > Meningococci > H. influenzae
  • 3 years to 20 years: Meningococci
  • > 20 years: Pneumococci

 

Additional Information

questions.text: A patient who has a pet dog, came with a complaint of hypochondrial pain. The radiological imaging showed cyst within the liver. What can be the causative organism? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Echinococcus granulosus

 

The key points that indicate Echinococcus granulosus as the causative organism are:

 

  1. The patient has a pet dog, which is the definitive host for Echinococcus granulosus (also known as the dog tapeworm).
  2. The patient presented with hypochondrial pain, which could be caused by the formation of cyst in the liver.
  3. Radiological imaging revealed a cyst within the liver, which is characteristic of Echinococcus granulosus infection.

 

Echinococcus granulosus is a cestode (tapeworm) parasite that causes hydatid cyst disease, primarily affecting the liver and lungs. The life cycle involves dogs (or other canids like wolves and foxes) as the definitive hosts, where the adult tapeworm resides in the intestine. The eggs are passed in the feces of these definitive hosts and can contaminate food or water sources.

 

Humans become accidental intermediate hosts by ingesting these eggs. Once ingested, the eggs hatch in the human intestine, and the larvae migrate to various organs, most commonly the liver (70-80% of cases), where they develop into unilocular hydatid cyst.

 

 

 

Life cycle

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Entamoeba histolytica: This is a protozoan parasite that causes amebic liver abscesses, not multilocular cysts. It is not transmitted by dogs and does not form characteristic multilocular cysts.

 

Option C. Taenia solium: Also known as the pork tapeworm, this organism can cause cysticercosis, where cysts form in muscle, brain, and other tissues, but it's not primarily known for liver cysts.

 

Option D. Diphyllobothrium latum: This is a fish tapeworm that primarily leads to vitamin B12 deficiency and megaloblastic anemia, not liver cysts.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Echinococcus granulosus, also known as the dog tapeworm, can cause hydatid cyst disease in humans, with multilocular cysts commonly found in the liver. Owning a pet dog and ingesting food or water contaminated with dog feces containing the parasite's eggs are risk factors for acquiring this infection.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis in a child presenting with chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and parenchymal calcifications? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Toxoplasma

 

The presentation of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and parenchymal calcifications is highly indicative of congenital toxoplasmosis. Toxoplasmosis is caused by the protozoan Toxoplasma gondii, which can infect the fetus during pregnancy if the mother acquires the infection. The classic triad of congenital toxoplasmosis includes:

 

  1. Chorioretinitis
  2. Hydrocephalus
  3. Diffuse parenchymal calcifications

 

These parenchymal calcifications are distributed throughout the brain tissue, which is a key distinguishing feature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Zika virus: Zika virus infections are primarily associated with microcephaly, calcifications in both the gray and white matter, and other severe brain malformations, not specifically with parenchymal calcifications along with hydrocephalus and chorioretinitis.

 

Option C. Rubella: Congenital rubella syndrome can lead to multiple defects, including hearing loss, heart defects, and cataracts. However, it is not typically associated with the triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and parenchymal calcifications.

 

Option D. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): Congenital CMV infection is commonly associated with periventricular calcifications rather than diffuse parenchymal calcifications. This means calcifications are found around the ventricles of the brain rather than throughout the parenchyma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and parenchymal calcifications is characteristic of congenital toxoplasmosis.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presented with complaints of diarrhea and foul-smelling stool. His stool microscopy did not show any ova or eggs, but there was the presence of motile 200 μm larva. Identify the organism. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

The Ans.  is Strongyloides stercoralis because this organism is known for producing motile larvae rather than eggs in the stool, which aligns with the findings in this patient. Strongyloides stercoralis is unique among the listed options in that it is ovoviviparous: it produces eggs that hatch into larvae inside the host. This explains why motile larvae, rather than eggs or ova, are observed in stool microscopy.

 

This characteristic is crucial for distinguishing Strongyloides from other helminths, particularly in immunocompromised patients like those with HIV, where the infection can become disseminated and more severe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma duodenale: This organism typically shows eggs, not larvae, in stool samples. It is a type of hookworm, and its diagnostic stage involves eggs rather than motile larvae.

 

Option B. Ascaris lumbricoides: Ascaris is diagnosed by finding eggs in the stool, not larvae. It is a large roundworm whose diagnostic stage in stool is the presence of characteristic eggs.

 

Option C. Schistosoma mansoni: Schistosoma species are identified by the presence of characteristic eggs in stool or urine, depending on the species. Motile larvae are not seen in stool samples for Schistosoma infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Strongyloides stercoralis is diagnosed by the presence of motile larvae in stool, distinguishing it from other helminths that typically show eggs in stool samples.

questions.text: Based on the given structural features, identify the type of antibody depicted. (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgA

 

Based on the structural description from the transcript, this question presents a dimeric antibody structure with two antibodies joined by a J-chain (joining chain). IgA is the only immunoglobulin that exists in both monomeric and dimeric forms. The secretory IgA found in mucus secretions exists as a dimer, with two IgA molecules connected by a J-chain and associated with a secretory component. This dimeric structure allows IgA to function effectively in mucosal immunity by providing enhanced binding and stability in secretions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgG: This antibody exists only in monomeric form and is the most abundant immunoglobulin in serum. It does not form dimeric structures with J-chains.

 

 

Option C. IgM: This antibody exists as a pentamer (five antibodies joined together by J-chains), not a dimer. It is the first antibody produced during immune response and has the highest molecular weight.

 

 

Option D. IgE: This antibody exists only in monomeric form and is primarily involved in allergic reactions and parasitic infections. It does not form dimeric structures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

IgA is the only antibody that can exist in dimeric form (connected by J-chains) when secreted in mucosal surfaces, while existing as a monomer in serum.

questions.text: DOC for fasciola hepatica: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Triclabendazole

 

Triclabendazole is the drug of choice for treating Fasciola hepatica (liver fluke) infections because:

 

  • It is the latest and most effective drug available
  • Has excellent activity against both immature and mature flukes
  • Single dose treatment is often effective
  • Well-tolerated with minimal side effects
  • WHO recommended first-line treatment

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Albendazole:

 

  • More effective against nematodes
  • Limited efficacy against liver flukes
  • Not recommended as first-line therapy for fascioliasis

 

Option C. Mebendazole:

 

  • Primarily used for treating intestinal nematodes
  • Poor absorption and bioavailability
  • Not effective against liver flukes

 

Option D. Praziquantel:

 

  • While effective against most trematodes
  • Has poor efficacy against Fasciola species
  • Used mainly for schistosomiasis and other fluke infections

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triclabendazole is the drug of choice for treating Fasciola hepatica (liver fluke) infections.

questions.text: A patient presented with retro-orbital pain and rash since the 5 days. Most appropriate test to be done now is:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Antibody detection by ELISA

 

When diagnosing dengue fever, the timing of the test is crucial. Dengue virus infection can be diagnosed by detecting the virus, its RNA, or its antigens, as well as by detecting antibodies against the virus.

 

NS1 Ag ELISA (Option A) and Dengue RNA by PCR (Option B) are methods used to detect the presence of the dengue virus or its antigens in the early stages of the infection, typically within the first 1-5 days of symptom onset. This is because the viral load and antigen levels are highest during this period.

 

Antibody detection by ELISA (Option C) becomes more appropriate after the initial phase of infection, typically after 5-7 days. At this point, the patient's immune system has started producing antibodies (IgM and IgG) against the virus, which can be detected using ELISA.

 

Viral culture (Option D), while definitive, is not typically used in routine clinical practice due to its complexity, cost, and time requirements.

 

Since the patient has been symptomatic for 5 days, it is likely that antibodies have begun to be produced. Therefore, the most appropriate test at this stage is the detection of antibodies by ELISA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NS1 Ag ELISA: This test is most effective within the first 1-5 days of infection when the NS1 antigen is present in the blood. After this period, its sensitivity decreases.

 

Option B. Dengue RNA by PCR: This test is also most effective within the first 1-5 days of infection for detecting the viral RNA. After this period, the viral load decreases, making the test less effective.

 

Option D. Viral culture: This method is not commonly used in routine practice due to its complexity and time-consuming nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient presenting with dengue symptoms for more than 5 days, the most appropriate diagnostic test is antibody detection by ELISA, as antibodies are typically present after 5-7 days of infection.

questions.text: Which bacterial toxin acts by interfering with EF-2 function? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diphtheria

 

Explanation:

 

Diphtheria toxin inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylating elongation factor 2 (EF-2), blocking its function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clostridium: Produces toxins, but they do not target EF-2.

 

Option C. Bacillus: Associated with different toxins not affecting EF-2.

 

Option D. Vibrio: Known for cholera toxin affecting intestinal secretion, not EF-2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diphtheria toxin uniquely targets EF-2, crucial for understanding its mechanism of action in causing disease by inhibiting protein synthesis.

questions.text: Among the options provided, which protozoan parasite is found within Kupffer cells? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leishmania donovani

 

  • Kupffer cells are macrophages of Liver.
  • Amastigote form of Leishmania donovani is engulfed by macrophages monocytes, and other reticuloendothelial cells → LD-body
  • LD bodies seen in peripheral smear of a patient with Kala azar

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toxoplasma: In the human host, the parasites form tissue cysts, most commonly in skeletal muscle, myocardium, brain, and eyes

 

Option C. Babesia’s life cycle doesn’t involve liver. Sporozoites directly enter RBCs.

 

Option D. Plasmodium vivax: In the pre-erythrocytic stage, plasmodium sporozoites invade hepatocytes, where they undergo development into merozoites. Subsequently, these merozoites infiltrate red blood cells (RBCs).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The amastigote form of Leishmania donovani, also known as LD bodies, is found within macrophages, including Kupffer cells in the liver, during infection.

questions.text: Which of the following is a gram-positive organism that shows the following appearance on Ziehl-Neelsen staining? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nocardia

 

The characteristic morphology of Nocardia is a branching, filamentous, gram-positive rod when observed under the microscope. Nocardia can resemble Actinomyces species on gram stain.  However, Nocardia is an obligate aerobe that stains weakly positive on acid-fast staining.

 

Nocardia is typically weakly acid-fast after traditional carbol-fuchsin staining and positive on modified acid-fast staining due to the presence of mycolic acid in the cell wall. Unlike mycobacteria (also acid-fast positive), Nocardia has a “beaded” appearance on acid-fast staining. Nocardia is catalase-positive and urease positive.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacilli are acid fast but non-branching

 

 

Option C. Mycobacterium leprae bacilli are less acid and alcohol fast than the tubercle bacillus; therefore, 10% sulphuric acid is used as a decolorizer in place of acid/alcohol solution.

 

 

Option D. Actinomyces are gram-positive but non-acid-fast in contrast to Nocardia.

 

The following image shows the filamentous gram-positive stained actinomyces:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocardia can be identified by its branching filamentous structure on gram stain and weak acid-fast positivity due to the presence of mycolic acid in its cell wall, distinguishing it from other gram-positive and acid-fast organisms.

questions.text: The organism with following life cycle is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

The given life cycle is of Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

Infective form - Filariform larvae

 

Natural host – Man

 

Mode of infection – penetration of skin by filariform larvae and autoinfection


 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ancylostoma duodenale is a hookworm that infects humans through skin penetration by its larvae.

 

Option C. Ascaris lumbricoides is a roundworm that infects humans through ingestion of contaminated food or water.

 

Option D. Enterobius vermicularis is a pinworm that infects humans through ingestion of its eggs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis involves skin penetration by filariform larvae and autoinfection.

questions.text: Match the following eggs to the organism? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

 

1. The Hymenolepis nana egg - The egg is roughly spherical or ovoid, 30-40 μm size. It has a thin colorless outer membrane and inner embryopore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere.  The space between two membranes contains yolk granules and 4-8 thread like polar filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore. The eggs float in saturated solution of salt and are non-bile stained. They are immediately infective and unable to survive for more than 10 days in external environment.

 

 

2. Ascaris lumbricoides (Roundworm)

 

Two types of eggs are passed by the worms: (1) fertilized and (2) unfertilized.

 

  1. The fertilized eggs, laid by females, inseminated by mating with a male, are embryonated and develop into the infective eggs (Figs 3A to C. .
  2. The unfertilized eggs, are laid by uninseminated female. These are nonembryonated and cannot become infective

 

Features of roundworm egg

 

 

 

3. The egg of Ancylostoma duodenale (hookworm) is:

 

Oval or elliptical, measuring 60 μm by 40 mcm.

 

Colorless, not bile stained.

 

Surrounded by a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane.

 

Floats in saturated salt solution.

 

When released by the worm in the intestine, the egg contains an unsegmented ovum.

 

During its passage down the intestine, the ovum develops. When passed in feces, the egg contains a segmented ovum, usually with four or eight blastomeres.

 

There is a clear space between the segmented ovum and the egg shell (Figs A and B).

 

 

4. The eggs of Taenia solium and Tania saginata are indistinguishable.

 

The egg is spherical, measuring 30-40 mcm diameter. lt has a thin hyaline embryonic membrane around it, which soon disappears after release. The inner embryophore is radially striated and is yellow brown due to bile staining. In the center is a fully-developed embryo (oncosphere) with three pairs of hooklets (hexacanth embryo). The eggs do not float in saturated salt solution. The eggs of T. saginata are infective only to cattle and not to humans, whereas the eggs of T. solium are infective to pigs and humans too.

questions.text: Which of the following components of the fungal cell wall is not seen in mucormycosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beta 1, 3, glucan

 

An abundant cell wall polysaccharide, (1-3)-β-d-glucan (BDG) is found in most fungi, with the notable exception of the cryptococci, the zygomycetes (mucor and Rhizopus), and Blastomyces dermatitidis, which either lack the glucan entirely or produce it at minimal levels.

 

Fungal cell wall:

 

  • Fungal cell walls are rigid and contain complex polysaccharides called chitin (adds structural strength) and glucans.
  • Ergosterol is the steroid molecule in the cell membranes that replaces the cholesterol found in animal cell membranes.

 

Clinical significance of Beta-1, 3-d-glucan:

 

G-test: Detects a-3 glucan. Used in diagnosis of candidiasis.

 

Tests for beta-d-glucan: Raised levels are seen in candidiasis, aspergillosis, and pneumonia due to Pneumocystis carnii.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mannoproteins: Mannoproteins are glycoproteins found in the fungal cell wall, contributing to its structure and function.

 

Option C. Chitin: Chitin is a structural polysaccharide found in the cell walls of fungi, including those causing mucormycosis. It provides rigidity and strength to the cell wall.

 

Option D. Ergosterol: Ergosterol is a component of fungal cell membranes, not the cell wall. It replaces cholesterol found in animal cell membranes and is essential for maintaining membrane integrity and function in fungi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta 1, 3, glucan is absent or minimally present in the cell walls of fungi causing mucormycosis, distinguishing them from many other fungi that have this polysaccharide as a major cell wall component. This characteristic is significant in the diagnosis and treatment of fungal infections.

questions.text: A farmer presents with a swollen foot and multiple sinuses as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mycetoma

 

The most likely diagnosis here is Mycetoma which is caused by Eumycetoma.

 

Mycetoma is an uncommon chronic granulomatous infective disease of the skin/dermis and subcutaneous tissues. “Madura Foot” or “Maduramycosis,” it is caused by true fungi (eumycetoma) or by the filamentous bacteria (actinomycetoma).

 

It is characterized by a triad of tumefaction, draining sinuses and the presence of colonial grains in the exudates. It is seen commonly in people who walk barefoot. Eumycetoma is more common in Northern India, while Actinomycetoma is more common in Southern India.

 

The two main groups of mycetoma are the Actinomycotic and Eumycotic groups. Actinomycetoma is caused by a group of filamentous bacteria which include Nocardia and Streptomyces species. The Nocardia species include Nocardia asteroids, Nocardia braziliensis and Nocardia caviae. The Streptomyces species include Streptomyces madurae, Streptomyces pelletieri and Streptomyces somaliensis.

 

The color of the grains found in the discharge is indicative of the species and helps to initiate appropriate treatment.

 

The foot is the most commonly affected and the dorsal aspect of the left foot for unexplained reasons is more affected.

 

The grains are histologically seen as sulfur granules surrounded by neutrophils which lead to a purulent tissue reaction containing fibroblasts. This prevents the antibiotic from acting on the micro-organisms, hence the need for debridement in certain cases.

 

Combined drug therapy is preferred to a single drug therapy to avoid resistance and any residual infection.

 

Surgical debridement, followed by prolonged appropriate antibiotic therapy for several months is required for actinomycetoma while a combination therapy with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (14 mg/kg, twice daily), dapsone (1.5 mg/kg, twice daily) and streptomycin (14 mg/kg) has been used along with Rifampicin for resistant cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma: Typically presents as a non-healing ulcer or nodule and does not exhibit the characteristic draining sinuses and grains seen in mycetoma.

 

Option C. Nocardia: Nocardia can cause mycetoma (specifically actinomycetoma), but in the context of the broad diagnosis, mycetoma is the more inclusive and accurate term.

 

Option D. Sporotrichosis: Caused by Sporothrix schenckii, usually presents with nodular lesions along lymphatic channels rather than multiple sinuses and grains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycetoma is characterized by swelling, draining sinuses, and colonial grains in exudates, and is common among individuals who walk barefoot. The diagnosis is supported by clinical presentation, histology, and the color of the grains. Treatment involves surgical debridement and prolonged antibiotic therapy for actinomycetoma or antifungal therapy for eumycetoma.

choices.text: It is caused by Burkholderia mallei.
It is endemic to Southeast Asia.
It can present similarly to Pulmonary Tuberculosis.
The bacterium is considered a potential biowarfare agent.

questions.text: Which of the following statements concerning Melioidosis is incorrect? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A (It is caused by Burkholderia mallei).

 

Explanation:

Melioidosis is caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei, not Burkholderia mallei. B. pseudomallei is a saprophyte found in soil and water in endemic regions. It causes a disease called melioidosis which has been nicknamed the "Vietnam time-bomb disease" due to its ability to remain latent for many years before activating. B. mallei, on the other hand, is a strictly zoonotic pathogen that causes glanders and farcy in horses and other equids.

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is endemic to Southeast Asia - This statement is true. Melioidosis is endemic to Southeast Asia, particularly in Thailand, Vietnam, Malaysia, Singapore and northern Australia. The bacterium B. pseudomallei is found in soil and water in these regions, where environmental conditions favor its survival.

 

Option C. It can present similarly to Pulmonary Tuberculosis - This statement is true. One of the clinical presentations of melioidosis is sub-acute pulmonary infection that can range from mild bronchitis to severe tuberculosis-like pneumonia. This tuberculosis-like presentation is one reason why melioidosis is often called "the great mimicker" in endemic regions.

Option D. The bacterium is considered a potential biowarfare agent - This statement is true. B. pseudomallei is classified as a potential agent of biological warfare due to its environmental persistence, relatively low infectious dose when aerosolized, resistance to many common antibiotics, and the serious nature of the disease it causes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Melioidosis is caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei (not B. mallei), can present with a variety of clinical manifestations from acute septicemia to chronic suppurative infections, and requires prolonged antibiotic therapy typically consisting of an intensive phase with ceftazidime or a carbapenem followed by an extended eradication phase with oral antibiotics.

questions.text: A Gram stain of periorbital exudate in a case of severe panophthalmitis with cellulitis in an elderly diabetic patient reveals irregular, broad, aseptate branching hyphae. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Apophysomyces sp

 

Explanation:

 

The microscopic finding of irregular, broad, aseptate branching hyphae in a periorbital exudate is characteristic of zygomycosis (mucormycosis/phycomycosis). Zygomycetes (including Apophysomyces species) feature broad, ribbon-like, non-septate (or sparsely septate) hyphae that often show irregular branching. This infection commonly presents as rhinocerebral (rhino-orbito-cerebral) form, affecting the nose, nasal sinuses, and orbit, especially in patients with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus as seen in this elderly diabetic patient with panophthalmitis and cellulitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida: Incorrect because Candida appears as oval or spherical budding cells (yeast) with pseudohyphae, not as broad aseptate hyphae. Candida forms are typically Gram-positive yeast cells with or without pseudohyphae.

 

Option B. Aspergillus: Incorrect because Aspergillus species produce narrow (2-10 μm), septate, hyaline hyphae with dichotomous branching at acute angles. The hyphae described in the question are aseptate, not the septate hyphae characteristic of Aspergillus.

 

Option C. Penicillium: Incorrect because Penicillium, like Aspergillus, produces septate hyphae, not the aseptate hyphae seen in this case. Penicillium has septate hyphae with branched conidiophores resembling a brush.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Rhinocerebral zygomycosis (mucormycosis) is a life-threatening opportunistic infection that typically presents with broad, aseptate hyphae on microscopic examination and has a strong association with diabetes mellitus with ketoacidosis. Rapid diagnosis and treatment are essential due to its high mortality rate.

choices.text: The First Generation QuantiFERON-TB assay utilized ESAT-6
The Second Generation QuantiFERON-TB (Gold) assay uses both ESAT-6 and CFP-10
These tests can differentiate between Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection and active disease
No non-tuberculous mycobacteria produce a positive reaction in this assay

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Gamma-Release-Assays for the diagnosis of Tuberculosis is correct? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. The Second Generation QuantiFERON-TB (Gold) assay uses both ESAT-6 and CFP-10

 

Explanation:

 

The QuantiFERON-TB Gold (second generation) assay utilizes two specific antigens - ESAT-6 (Early Secretory Antigenic Target-6) and CFP-10 (Culture Filtrate Protein-10) for detecting TB infection. These antigens are present in M. tuberculosis complex but absent in BCG vaccine strains and most non-tuberculous mycobacteria, making them more specific for TB detection compared to tuberculin skin tests.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: The First Generation QuantiFERON-TB assay utilized ESAT-6 This is incorrect because the first generation QuantiFERON-TB assay used tuberculin PPD (purified protein derivative) as the stimulating antigen, not ESAT-6. This made it less specific than the second generation test.

 

Option C: These tests can differentiate between Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection and active disease This is incorrect as IGRAs (Interferon-Gamma Release Assays) including QuantiFERON cannot differentiate between latent TB infection and active TB disease. They only detect immune response to TB antigens, indicating exposure or infection.

 

Option D: No non-tuberculous mycobacteria produce a positive reaction in this assay This is incorrect because some non-tuberculous mycobacteria (such as M. kansasii, M. marinum, and M. szulgai) also possess genes for ESAT-6 and CFP-10, potentially causing false-positive results in the assay.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The QuantiFERON-TB Gold assay uses ESAT-6 and CFP-10 antigens to improve specificity over the first generation test, but still cannot distinguish between latent infection and active disease.

questions.text: Which fungus is most commonly associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rhizopus

 

Rhizopus is the most common fungus associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis.

 

Diabetic patients are immunocompromised and so prone to develop opportunistic infections. Orbital cellulitis with Rhizopus may turn fatal in these patients as it is an angioinvasive fungus and could lead to septicemia and thromboses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida: Incorrect, although Candida is a common opportunistic pathogen, it is more frequently associated with mucocutaneous and systemic infections rather than orbital cellulitis.

 

Option C. Aspergillus: Incorrect, Aspergillus can cause a variety of infections including orbital cellulitis, but it is not the most common cause in the context of diabetic ketoacidosis.

 

Option D. Trichophyton: Incorrect, Trichophyton primarily causes skin infections such as ringworm and athlete's foot, and is not typically associated with orbital cellulitis.

 

Educational Objective:
